thread.title: Ebony Fair re-created at Fashion Week
thread.title_full: Ebony Fair re-created at Fashion Week

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Ebony Fair re-created at Fashion Week
text:
Classic designs are timeless, so says Meghan Mundy, chief fashion officer for Fashion Week of Rochester. With that idea in mind, Mundy set out to create a runway show that celebrates vintage fashion for this year's Fashion Week of Rochester, a six-day event that kicks off Oct. 13.
Called Midtown Funk, the vintage fashion show Thursday night will feature emerging designers and a re-creation of the famous Ebony Fashion Fair shows that made stops in Rochester.
Christian Dior, Yves St. Laurent, Oscar de la Renta, Pierre Cardin, Patrick Kelly, Christian Lacroix and Alexander McQueen are just a few of the designers who created couture clothing especially for Ebony Fashion Fair, which started in Chicago in 1958 and continued through the '60s, '70s, '80s and '90s. This traveling spectacular helped to redefine the concepts of beauty, style and empowerment for African American women.
Back then, black women were not featured as models on the runway or in magazines, says Mary Nicosia, a Rochester vintage fashion collector. Ebony Fashion Fair, which was sponsored by Ebony Magazine , sought to change that, showing that black women are beautiful.
The Fashion Week shows explore the 50-year history of Ebony Fashion Fair, which emerged at the time of the civil rights movement, says Nicosia, who is loaning her collection of vintage gowns and jewels for the event.
At a recent fitting, Nicosia worked her magic on models ready to strut the runway. She fitted her burgundy evening gown loaded with feathers on the model and accessorized the dress with matching costume jewelry. The look evokes the elegance of years past.
Buy Photo Mary Z. Nicosia, private vintage clothing collector, likes the look as model Aubrey Oates, Rochester, models a Roberto Cavalli dress as she tries on outfits in preparation for Fashion Week. (Photo: SHAWN DOWD/@sdowdphoto/, STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)
Memorial Art Gallery is a co-sponsor of the show and will share images from the upcoming museum exhibition, Inspiring Beauty: 50 years of Ebony Fashion Fair, which arrives at the museum on Jan. 31. Thursday's Fashion Week event will show projected images of the exhibition with models on the runway donning fashion from local designers and vintage couture from local collectors. While the gallery show is an exhibition, there will be an opportunity to dress up with a members-only party on Jan. 30 and a public party on Jan. 31.There will also be a gala party in April.
The Ebony Fashion Fair traveled to Rochester as early as 1962, says MAG spokeswoman Meg Colombo. Over the next 50 years, the traveling fashion show helped raise millions for charity and the profile of Johnson Publishing Co., publisher of Ebony and Jet magazines.
Show organizers overcame racial prejudice to bring fashion to people eager to see a new black America. Eunice Johnson of the publishing company took over as producer and director in 1963 as the traveling show gained new audiences.
The traveling exhibit fits with the Memorial Art Gallery's mission of inclusiveness and culture, Colombo says.
There is something magical about the 1960s era, says Joan Lincoln, owner of Panache Vintage and Finer Consignments in Brighton who is also providing fashions for the Midtown Funk show.
"It was a time when women really dressed up,' she says.
Lincoln points to a pale pink satin dress with embroidery and a matching jacket. The look is perfect for a night on the town, she says.
Vintage fashion is making a comeback as many women seek out the classic glamour, Lincoln says. Her shop carries many styles in myriad price points.
From the elegance of the 1960s, Lincoln selected contrasting looks to showcase the glitz of the 1980s. Sequins and gold reign supreme in the 1980s vintage styles.
This year, Fashion Week of Rochester will host its runway shows in one location under a large tent, similar to fashion weeks in larger cities. The 15,000-square-foot tent on Main Street downtown, across from the Sibley Building, will feature a nearly 100-foot raised runway, seating and standing room for more than 900 people and a retail and food vendor area.
Fashion Week 2015 kicks off Tuesday with a free Fashion Exchange at the tent, where people can trade in gently used items from their closets for something new. The week's five runway shows will start Wednesday and continue through Saturday. The annual shopping event, the Boutique Crawl, will round out the week on Sunday, Oct. 18.
It is the sixth year annual event, which started with just two runway shows. The show grows every year and is a major fundraiser for the Center for Youth that helps area young people in need.
Mundy and Center for Youth Executive Director Elaine Spaull lead the charge on Fashion Week productions. Each year, the event gets bigger and there are always surprises, Mundy says.
Midtown Funk, featuring re-creations from Ebony Fashion Fair, is just one example of how Fashion Week is switching things up. Inspirations from the past keep fashion moving forward, Mundy says.
"There's a huge interest in vintage," Mundy says. "Current designers draw their designs from vintage fashions."
MCHAO@Gannett.com
Buy Photo Kaydian Hayle, Rochester, looks over the vintage Victor Costa dress with duck feather trim as she tries on outfits in preparation for Fashion Week. (Photo: SHAWN DOWD/@sdowdphoto/, STAFF PHOTOGRAPHER)
Day-by-day highlights
Fashion Exchange , 3 to 8 p.m. Tuesday: Bring new or gently used clothing, shoes or accessories and trade them in for something new. Choose from inventory contributed by local boutiques.
Fashion 9 to 5 , noon Wednesday: This lunchtime runway show features business wear, daytime dresses and classic day-to-night looks.
Puppy Love , 7:30 p.m. Wednesday: Dogs will accompany human models on the runway. Both will be dressed in their finest in a show that features accessories, including hats, jewelry, purses, boots, coats and rainwear.
Midtown Funk , 8 p.m. Thursday: This runway show will feature redheads, emerging designers and — in collaboration with the Memorial Art Gallery — a re-creation of the famous Ebony Fashion Fair.
We Are Family , 7:30 p.m. Friday: This multi-generational runway show celebrates families, including twins, sisters and brothers and "silver foxes" who remind us that style never ages.
Saturday Night Fever , 8 p.m. Saturday, Oct. 17: The 2015 finale show will bring classic and glamorous designs to the runway, including collections from Polish designer Viola Spiechowicz, all to an upbeat dance theme.
Boutique Crawl , 10 a.m. registration at City Grill, 384 East Ave., Rochester; 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sunday, Oct. 18: A self-guided tour of area boutiques.
Fashion Week tickets ($25/$50) are available at Wegmans. For more information, go to fashionweekofrochester.org .

Fashion Week Coverage
Follow Mary this week at @MaryChaoStyle for the latest from the runways. Meet her on Friday, Oct. 16, at the We Are Family fashion show, where she is modeling with her daughter. Watch for more coverage at DemocratandChronicle.com and rochmagazine.com throughout the week.
